comments:
When the Launcher dialog is used to edit launcher definitions, it encounters a
path that causes an exception, and then greys out the APPLY button so we are
unable to apply corrections.

The details of the problem launcher definitions are that they reference an
absolute path originally defined on a WindowsXP machine c:\blah\blah.  These are
then checked into CVS from the WindowsXP workstation.  Then they are checked out
from CVS on a Linux workstation. (This can probably be simulated.)  The path
c:\blah\blah is read and interpreted as a relative path where an absolute path
is required (/home/ratboy/workspaces/blah/blah) .

The expected behavior should be for the Launcher dialog to flag with a red 'X'
in the usual fashion, and allow the user to correct the problem paths while
negotiating a cross-platform path solution with the rest of the team.



The dialog's response to the exception is to grey out the apply button, and
correcting the path does not enable the APPLY button.

Created an attachment (id=20021)
Debug UI patch

Also need org.eclipse.jdt.launching.patch to fix this bug.

Created an attachment (id=20022)
JDT Launching patch

Also need org.eclipse.jdt.debug.ui.patch to fix this bug.

Dan, after applying the patches, I found that I was not able to add a jar to 
the classpath that originated from the workspace, rather than the "external" 
local file system.

Created an attachment (id=20085)
Debug UI Patch V2

Got a little over-ambitious with my path integrity checking. Simplified to only
handle the relative path case that was in 88939.

I got a little too clever on the fix, not realizing the differences between
external and project-based classpath entries. This should fix the case in the
bug fix, but I once we are open for business on 3.2, I wouldn't mind making this
stuff a little smarter. For example, it would be nice if the dialogs gave you
warnings for library resources that didn't exist. Maybe a nice icon or
something. In order to do that nicely, I think IRuntimeClassPathEntry should
have an isValid() method or something to that effect.

Verified. Modified error message slightly that is displayed in Java classpath
tab to read "Archive does not exist: {path}".

It would be nice to have an error overlay for invalid paths. I will open (and
defer) a new feature request for that.

traces.message: Assertion failed; Path for IClasspathEntry must be absolute
